Currency and Controversy

By James Bithell

With the appearance of Nelson Mandela on South African notes breaking with convention, George Wood explores some of the weird, contentious and outright offensive designs to hit the world's presses.

Calum Macdiarmid: Commercialism and Creativity

By James Bithell

Calum Macdiarmid, fresh from the Aesthetica Short Film Festival's screening of his award-winning short film, 82, talks to Fliss Turner about aesthetics, art, and why he clings to expressionism.

Ali Ferzat: A Pen of Damascus Steel

By James Bithell

Time Magazine's 100 most influential people of 2012 included a man who has been kidnapped, tortured and exiled for his satirical attacks on the Assad regime. Laura Hughes meets Ali Ferzat.

The Modern Sloane Identity

Peter York has stood at the epicentre of elite culture for over thirty years. Tom Witherow finds out who's running London, what's posh and why Made in Chelsea simply isn't. (Thumbnail credit Peter York; (c) Johnny Greig)

Brewing for Britain

A recipe for beer brought by monks fleeing post-revolution France has been discovered within Ampleforth Abbey. Martin Spurr finds out how the monks are stepping up production.

Offending the System

One of the UK's leading criminologists David Wilson speaks to Ally Swadling about the need for penal reform, dispelling prison stereotypes, and how to spot a serial killer.

A Hundred Years of Heist

A haul from a museum in Rotterdam last month proves art heist is big business. Fiona Parker looks back at the most notorious robberies of the last century, and sees why it may not be such a great business model after all.

The Syrian Fallout

David Willey, expert in managing the fallout in post-war disaster zones tells Laura Hughes of the plight of Syrian refugees, and what we can do to divert the attention of the international community.

The Original Freshers

Has Freshers week at York always been the same? Bella Foxwell talks to the trendsetting freshers of the 60s to find out.

The Pride of the North

For decades the North of England lagged behind in the bid for gay equality. Stefan Roberts and Tom Witherow finds out what's changed

My Daughter, The Terrorist

By James Bithell

The Sri Lankan civil war was notorious for the atrocities committed. Laura Hughes finds out why the war left some women without any choice but to sign up.

A Real Love Story

Camila Batmanghelidjh, Founder of the charity Kids Company, speaks about the role of neuropsychology in her work with victims of abuse and neglect

Bears for Belarus

A thousand teddy bears were parachuted into Minsk last month, sparking a new wave of international protest against Lukashenko's dictatorship. Neil Johnston speaks to Liberal Youth activist Sam Fisk to find out more.

Studying Down Under

A year abroad can seem a daunting prospect as a Fresher. Femke Gow explains why she's never looked back after her year in Australia.

Top 10 moments of the 2012 Olympics

These sixteen days have produced some fantastic moments both in the sporting arena and outside. Tom Witherow whittles the pack down to just ten.

I say Jeeves! What the Dickens has made us so popular?

Rekindle your penchant for Wodehouse's escapist idealism this Summer, says Tom Witherow

Food for the Future

Tim Lang, the man who coined the phrase 'food miles', talks to Laura Hughes about the sustainability, security and future of our food.

A Backbone for Britain

An ambitious proposal has been put forward by architectural firm Foster's. Josh Boswell finds out how it could revolutionise the North's economy. (Thumbnail credit All photos courtesy of Foster and Partners)

Entering The Conflict Zone

By James Bithell

How do you travel in Israel and Palestine, one of the most complicated, yet interesting regions in the world? (Thumbnail credit All photos: (c) Ailsa Wright 2012)

Burning the Man

A temporary city is created in the middle of the desert once a year. Sophie Rose Walker finds out whether anyone really knows what happens at Burning Man, the community that leaves no trace

Growing Alternatives

Primary Bone Cancer is the most common form of teenage cancer, yet the least understood. Fiona Parker uncovers the groundbreaking stem cell research being done here at the University of York.

Feeling numb: Simon Amstell

Ex-host of Buzzcocks and Popworld, Simon Amstell, talks to Ally Swadling about his stand-up, his sitcom and not being miserable. (Thumbnail credit Simon Amstell. Photo credit: seekernews)

Girls in the Ring

Women are to compete in Olympic boxing for the first time. Sophie Rose Walker investigates why Yorkshire is leading the way in getting girls into boxing (Thumbnail credit Caption: Kimberley Brown, Hull Saints ABC, Hull, East Yorkshire. Copyright Lee Karen Stow @ Girls in the Ring)

A Cultural iMovement

Creative Director of iMove, Tessa Gordziejko speaks to Tom Witherow about Yorkshire's Cultural Olympiad

One Rower's Blind Ambition

The Paralympic Games are a showcase of scientific achievement, but in one sport, it's just you and the boat. Fiona Parker investigates

From Stadium to Street

Francesca Strange talks to Bella Foxwell, about her role as a Young Leader and the other teenagers bringing Olympic spirit to their communities

The Price of Talent

By James Bithell

Britain's Got Talent draws audiences in the tens of millions, but at what cost? Bella Foxwell investigates (Thumbnail credit The BGT Parade)

Reliving the lives of billions: Tom Witherow talks to two people at York who, this week, are living off just a PS1 a day

Social media in China is heavily censored. Lam, Tsz Ying finds out whether users on the mainland really care
